Giorgia Meloni: Neo-fascist or far right? Why Italian PM's tenure raises questions among political experts
subhead: The Italian prime minister has been in power now for three years. Italy's political experts question the normalization of this leader, who comes from a neo-fascist background. Has her tenure really been accompanied by a moderation of her political views?

Khan Yunis: Occupied, bombed, razed and divided by Israel
subhead: The centuries-old city of Khan Yunis, located in the Gaza Strip, has paid a heavy price for its central role in Palestinian nationalism, to the point that it is now divided by Israel's so-called 'yellow line,' writes Jean-Pierre Filiu in his column for Le Monde.

title: Oona Chaplin: A fiery force in 'Avatar: Fire and Ash'
subhead: Charlie Chaplin's granddaughter brings Varang, the flamboyant 'villain' of the third installment of James Cameron's saga, to life.

title: Morocco faces 'obligation' to win AFCON 2025 and deliver flawless tournament
subhead: As favorites, the Atlas Lions take on Comoros on Sunday, December 21, in the opening match of the Africa Cup of Nations. This tournament serves as a test ahead of the 2030 World Cup, which Morocco will co-host with Spain and Portugal.

title: Madagascar's metalheads lead charge of anger: 'It's easier to make yourself heard when you scream'
subhead: After three weeks of protest, Madagascar's Generation Z succeeded in toppling those in power on October 14. The uprising drew much of its strength from countercultural circles, chief among them the island's vibrant metal scene. Heirs to a long tradition, Madagascar's metalheads condemn poverty, inequality and the regime's incompetence.

In Paris, the number of homeless living in outdoor camps continues to rise
subhead: Outreach teams counted 663 tents in the main encampment areas of the French capital at the end of November, representing between 985 and 1,723 people. The rise is driven by a reduction in available shelter spaces and tighter restrictions on residency permits.

title: 'The Gospel is a bombshell. 'Love your neighbor' is such a radical message': Charlotte's conversion to Catholicism
subhead: 'Changing Faith' (1/11). Why do people choose a particular religion? Charlotte, a 23-year-old philosophy student in Paris, embraced Christianity as a teenager, but maintains her distance from the Church as an institution. She recounts her spiritual journey.

title: Santa Claus in France is a temp worker: 'It helps make ends meet'
subhead: Retirees, actors, entrepreneurs: They don the role of Santa Claus in shopping malls, at Christmas markets or via video calls for private customers. Few people rush to apply for this job, which sometimes involves difficult working conditions, although the most experienced among them still appreciate it.
